places.name: Shaher ki Masjid
places.address: FGMJ+CJX Shaher ki Masjid, Champaner, Gujarat 389360

featured_reviews.review_id: A beautiful masjid built for the royal family in a joint Hindu and Islamic style. Hardly any crowd. Maintained well. Common ticket for Shaher ki masjid and Jami masjid
featured_reviews.review_text: A beautiful masjid built for the royal family in a joint Hindu and Islamic style. Hardly any crowd. Maintained well. Common ticket for Shaher ki masjid and Jami masjid

featured_reviews.review_id: This site is an awesome architectural design. You choos 2nd point after seeing jaami masjid. In this boundary you get shehar ki masjid, three cells and custom House. 2 hours enough for watching this site. The same tickets which you purchase from jaami masjid is ok for here. You must walk around the masjid boundaries or wall you will get some surprises. In the three cells there are lot of bats, carefully enter inside the structure.

featured_reviews.review_id: Shekar ki Masjid is one of the best Masjid in champaner area. This Masjid is built by great king Muhammad begada.  The pillars are symmetric and a great photographic location. This Mosque is built in 15th century in a mixed Islamic and Hindu architecture. It is constructed on a raised platform consisting of a large prayer hall with 5 mihrabs and two minarets. This is a prelude to the 3 main Mosque in the area.
featured_reviews.review_text: Shekar ki Masjid is one of the best Masjid in champaner area. This Masjid is built by great king Muhammad begada.  The pillars are symmetric and a great photographic location. This Mosque is built in 15th century in a mixed Islamic and Hindu architecture. It is constructed on a raised platform consisting of a large prayer hall with 5 mihrabs and two minarets. This is a prelude to the 3 main Mosque in the area.

featured_reviews.review_id: This is a beautiful old mosque complex. The tall minarets make it look awesome. It's a quiet and beautiful place. Make sure you wander around the compound including the back side.
featured_reviews.review_text: This is a beautiful old mosque complex. The tall minarets make it look awesome. It's a quiet and beautiful place. Make sure you wander around the compound including the back side.

featured_reviews.review_id:
This is another classical historic monument at champaner.
Look at the carvings, domes, place of worship.
Accompanied by a local guide would be a bonus in understanding and viewing this place.
An entry ticket of rs 40 applicable that is valid at other monuments too.
Parking and public convenience available.
Easily spend half an hour and have a look at nearby gates and fort walls.
Enjoy.

featured_reviews.review_id:
cNpaaner paavaagrh aarkiyoloNjikl  paark gujraat ke bdddhodraa shhr se puurv kii aur mhs 50 kimii duur hai to vhii godhraa se pshcim dishaa meN  68 kimii  duur hai /    cNpaaner paavaagrh meN  kii  mdhyyugiin aur praaciin imaarte hai jisme  mNdir msjid, kilaa ,mhl eNv sttepvel  shaamil haiN , iin imaartoN aur mNdiro kaa nirmaann 2 sdii se jisme 16 sdii ke biic huvaa haiN /  cNpaaner paavaagrh aarkiyoloNjikl  paark kul  3200 ekr se bhii jyaadaa ke eriaa meN phailaa hai aur yNhaa pr kul 114 monumeNtts haiN  /  yNhaa ke sbse khuubsuurt aur vishaal vstuoN meN shhr kii msjid shaamil hai /   msjid cNpaaner ke prmukh dvaar se prvesh krne pr  saamne hii dikhaaii detii hai /  .                              apne vaishissttpuurnn  sthaapty klaa aur khuubsuurtii ke kaarnn  shhr kii msjid bhii cNpaaner paavaagrh aarkiyoloNjikl  paark iis vishv dhrohr sthl kaa ek mhtvpuurnn hissaa hai / 

saal 2004 meN cNpaaner paavaagrh aarkiyoloNjikl  paark ko UNESCO ne apne vishv dhrohr kii suucii meN shaamil kiyaa /

featured_reviews.review_translated_text:
Champaner Pavagadh Archaeological Park is 50 km east of Vadodara city of Gujarat and 68 km west of Godhra. Champaner Pavagadh has many medieval and ancient buildings, including temples, mosques, forts, palaces and stepwells, these buildings and temples were built from the 2nd century to the 16th century. Champaner Pavagadh Archaeological Park is spread over a total area of   more than 3200 acres and there are a total of 114 monuments. The most beautiful and huge objects here include the mosque of the city. The mosque is visible right in front of Champaner upon entering from the main gate. , Due to its distinctive architecture and beauty, the mosque of the city is also an important part of the Champaner Pavagadh Archaeological Park, a World Heritage Site.

In the year 2004, UNESCO included Champaner Pavagadh Archaeological Park in its list of World Heritage.

featured_reviews.review_id: When I went there, there was no one although Pavagadh is crowded place. Few enlightened people visit these monuments (good for them). The entry ticket is Rs 40 and valid for Jama Masjid too

The entry fee is Rs 40 for each adult if you get it offline
Pre-booking online will be Rs. 35 each

featured_reviews.review_id:
Jami Masjid, Champaner A UNESCO World Heritage Site
"Jami Masjid, also known as Jama Masjid in Champaner, is a part of the Champaner-Pavagadh Archaeological Park. The historical city of Champaner was founded in the 8th century by Vanraj Chavda, the most prominent king of the Chavda Dynasty.

A UNESCO World Heritage Site, it is amongst the 114 monuments the Baroda Heritage Trust listed. The Jami Masjid is located about 150 feet east of the city walls near the eastern gate.

It is considered one of the finest mosques in western India with its elegant interiors. The ornamentation on the facade of mosques and tombs consists of symbols and motifs of the sun, diamond, pots, vines and lotus insignia, which were used in the earlier temples. The craftsman had imbibed their craft from their forefathers, who passed on the knowledge of Hindu, Muslim and Jain motifs.

Mahmud Begarha, born Fath Khan Mahmud (1445-1511), was among the most capable Sultans of Gujarat. In his long and prosperous reign (1458 onward), he expanded the borders of his domains, clashed successfully with the Portuguese, routed Malabar pirates, and established a new capital city at Champaner. Although his achievements laid a firm foundation for future rulers to build upon, his successors were not as capable. A mere 24 years after Mahmud Bergarha's death, the realm was annexed by Humayan of the newly-rising Mughal dynasty and lost any semblance of independence.

In 1484, when the Sultan defeated Chauhan Rajputs and occupied the site of Champaner, all that lay in the future. For the next 23 years, Bergarha spent untold resources rebuilding Champaner as a worthy capital of his domains, renaming it Muhammadabad. To those ends, he established heavily fortified walls enclosing palaces, mosques, gardens, tombs, and military garrisons. Although it was partly intended as a refuge for the Sultan in times of war, the city was not as strong as it appeared. When Humayan, the young emperor of the Mughals, laid siege to the city in 1535, his scouts were able to discover a deserted section of fortifications, allowing his soldiers to enter covertly. His forces then ransacked the city. Following his victory, the surviving population fled into the countryside, abandoning its buildings and surrounding fields. When a British surveying crew entered the ruins of Champaner in 1803, they found only 500 inhabitants in a city built for tens of thousands.

The mosque is located a mere 40 meters inside the city's east gate. It is oriented almost precisely east-west, with the qibla wall canted off-axis slightly to Mecca (although close enough to satisfy liturgical requirements). It comprises a rectangular main building facing a large courtyard surrounded by arcades. The front (east) facade is decorated with twin minarets, 36 meters high, flanking a central iwan with a five-meter wide opening. The octagonal minarets are deeply incised with horizontal moldings and small vertical niches infused with floral patterns. To either side of the minarets are flanking oriel windows supported by S-shaped Hindu-style brackets. The remainder of the building, extending to the north and south, includes two arches on each side, such that the whole ensemble reads as a five-part facade. Finally, anchoring the corners of the monument are cylindrical guldastas (corner turrets) topped by conical roofs.

Inside, the overall floor area measures 66 x 27 meters, about three-quarters the size of its antecedent in Ahmedabad. As is typical of congregational mosques the world over, the vast space is supported by columns, numbering here 176 in all. As the central mihrab can not be seen from all angles within the building (due to the presence of the columns), six additional mihrabs are placed on the qibla wall for the benefit of worshippers, three to each side. Short turrets on the outside of the west wall mark the location of each mihrab from the exterior.

featured_reviews.review_id:
Decent archaeological site. Built about 500 yrs ago, the whole archaeological park is a good experience for people interested in historical ruins.
Places to visit nearby include stepwells, 7manzil, 7kamaan and the ancient blackstone built temple whose creators are not known as of today.

Since we are from Mumbai, we were not sure of how to go about the visiting sequence and hence we ended up missing the temple on the top.

Since we are from Mumbai, we were not sure of how to go about the visiting sequence and hence we ended up missing the temple on the top.

featured_reviews.review_id: It's a 15th century, mosque and very well maintained by the  authority. Perhaps the best preserved mosque in entire Gujarat. The minarets are very tall and the jali art is superb. The best fusion of Indo Islamic art. Expect to spend at least a hour at this place as it makes a good photography place and is relatively crowd free.

Expect to spend at least a hour at this place as it makes a good photography place and is relatively crowd free.

featured_reviews.review_id: The ideal location for family hangouts is Champaner Fort. The sculpture and building are the best, most serene locations. The building's surrounding garden is lovely and beautiful. It is simple to get to. The ticket price for single person is 40 rs. Also it is World Heritage site. So it is must visit place if you are visiting the pavagadh mahakali maa temple.

So it is must visit place if you are visiting the pavagadh mahakali maa temple.

featured_reviews.review_id: Monsoon season has to be my favourite season to visit this Archeological site. Do bear in mind to carry cash with you as the network reception is quite bad here so you might face difficulties making UPI transactions to book tickets.

featured_question.question: Is it open now after COVID?

featured_reviews.review_id:
This mosque is seculeded. You will need to walk towards this. Car will not reach this place. Kevada Mosque (also Kewda or Kevda) is a mosque in Champaner, Gujarat state, western India. It is part of the Champaner-Pavagadh Archaeological Park, a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The mosque has minarets, globe-like domes, and narrow stairs. According to Ruggles (2008), nature was integrated into the Kevada mosque's architecture in a way that was unusual elsewhere in the Islamic world.

This mosque was built in Champaner during the time of Mahmud Begada, as were several other mosques, such as the Bawaman, Ek Minar, Jama, Khajuri, Nagina, and Shahar Ki. After James Burgess and Henry Cousens wrote descriptions of the Kevada, Jama, and Nagina Mosques, roads were built to reach them. The Kevada is notable because of its mausoleum. Kathra Mosque is west of the Kevada.

The mosque has many mihrabs, all intricately carved. There is a damaged brick tank for ablutions before prayers are offered at the mosque. The centotaph is square in shape with a fluted central dome and four corner domes; it is located next to the tank. The layout of the mosque is rectangular. Floral and geometrical designs adorn the niches. The tribate inter-columns are considered attractive. The prayer hall, a double storied structure, had three domes but the central dome has since disappeared. The windows have balconies built over pillars with intricate carved decorations. There are two minarets, which are also decorated with intricate carvings. Restoration works were carried out in the 1890s.

Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) reports of 2006 indicate that extensive restoration works were carried out at the Kevada Mosque and also at many other monuments in Champaner-Pavagadh Archaeological Park, the Jami Mosque, fort walls, Bawana Mosque, Lila Gubaz, Sikandar Shah Tomb and Sikander tomb, which resulted in a slight increase in tourist traffic to the sites.

featured_reviews.review_id:
Beautiful Monument in the champaner. This is 2 km outer from city and inside the village you can take same route of shehar ki masjid. Only car and bike can access. No ticket required. 1 hour is enough to visit this place.
Two main structure in this area, masjid and chabutra. Wajoo khana and one well is also in this area. Main dom of masjid is collapsed due to nature reason.

featured_reviews.review_id: One of the best mosque of the group of monuments of Champaner world heritage site ! Nicely kept but need to do some more maintenance. Main big problem is the approach street to this monument ! Only SUV can go there and also prepare for scratches on the sides of the car. Very narrow street as lots of Acasia bush trees grown both sides ! And big stones in between too. But chances to spot some wildlife too

It is under Archeological Survey of India. Garden also beautiful and this place is very calm.Good for pre-wedding shoutout and photography. It is simply amazing and beautiful place.

Worth a visit. Also Nagina Masjid close by.

featured_reviews.review_id: A real gem if you go to the right way.. A little bit secluded place, But Google map will take you to the right direction..  You may feel bit scary..Bring water  Enjoy the Place..
